rules.text: Be friendly, be respectful, stay on-topic and avoid derailing discussions.
No condescending or derogatory language, especially regarding race, nationality, color, gender, sexual preference, age, religion or political affiliation.
Use the CW (Content Warning) flag whenever you post something that you wouldn't want your neighbor, boss, coworker, partner or children to see.
No porn, no child sexual exploitation material, not even disguised as anime. Exceptions: occasional soft nudity of yourself or your consenting partner behind a CW.
Bots allowed as long as posts are relevant to this instance (Emacs, Programming Languages etc.)
Properly tag the language of your posts, so other users can auto-translate the content.

If you post links to media (videos, images, audio), please provide a short description of what the content is about. This helps the users and the moderators to better assess the content. We reserve the right to mark links to media as "sensitive" that the moderators cannot qualify.
Comply with the law of your country.
No introduction required, no real names required, but please put a few words in your bio.

This server is intended for non-commercial purposes, with the exception of directly related commercial activities that contribute to the server's topic (i.e. services related to FOSS, hosting, Emacs, books). Prior approval from administrators is required for recurring use.

records.text: After an epic battle, got SSSD's smartcard support talking to tpm2_pkcs11 (the following assumes you already have smartcard auth working in general):1. Patch tpm2_pkcs11's src/lib/slot.c:slot_get_info to add the CKF_REMOVABLE_DEVICE flag to the slot (sssd ignores non-removable devices). Install the patched version in the usual location, often /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/pkcs11. You can check that it worked with "pkcs11-tool -v -L --module /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/pkcs11/libtpm2_pkcs11.so" which should now include "removable device" in the slot flags.2. Set up a token in /etc/tpm2_pkcs11 with tpm2_ptool or whatever (this can and probably should be owned by root with mode 0600). Provision a suitable certificate, usually the same as on your trad-smartcard.3. Make /dev/tpmrm0 accessible for root: setfacl -m u:root:rw /dev/tpmrm0 (a udev rule can be set up to make this permanent). sssd's default CapabilityBoundingSet prevents p11_child (forked by sssd_pam) from overriding the owner/group for write access even as root.(4. Check SELinux/Apparmor restrictions if you're enforcing that stuff on sssd.)"pamtester lightdm your_username authenticate" should now prompt for the virtual smartcard PIN.If you haven't done it yet, use tpm2_dictionarylockout to set up the DA lockout and then use tpm2_changeauth to set a password on the lockout control object (using a random string and throwing it out is what Windows does and is probably a good idea). Setting up p11-kit-remote to talk to localhost might make it possible to skip some of the permission fuckery.Virtual smartcards may not be a good idea on a portable device (especially since tpm2_pkcs11 doesn't support PCR binding) but probably no worse than password auth on a desktop :shrug:

records.text: What custom view(s) do you have on your Org-agenda config ? Do you have sample of code to share ?I'm curious to see how people are using it.On my side, I have the following templates:* Personal tasks list: A simple "tags+todo" that filter to keep only the "me" tag* School tasks lists: Same as the previous one, but with a list for all school tasks and a list for only school evaluated tasks (both filtered by a "school" tag)* Association tasks list: Again, the same as the first view bet for an association I am a member of* Home tasks list: Same kind of list, but with all home related tasks like cleaning, buying stuff, etcMy views are not very complex or original. And I only use list made with "tags-todo".#OrgMode#Emacs

records.text: Henro Pilgrimage - Day 23 - May 8 (47km)Today I got a glimpse of my limits. At the moment I’m set up for the evening at a large dam in the mountains. I left the cape at 5:30 this morning and headed back up the eastern cost. The weather was perfect. Back near the long beach a local told me not to treck down the rockier path, since the rain had washed out the usual sand bridge. I went anyway and jumped the tiny river that had formed. No issue.By 10:30 I was back at the inn from the previous day and grabbed a quick lunch. That’s already a good 20km walk. There, I talked with the owner about my options for the evening. I was thinking about heading for a campsite a few hours up the road. He suggested I instead go another 10+ km further than that to a dam, saying there’s a park there where I could sleep wherever I want.I’ll get to the campsite first and then weigh my options.By 15:00 I was at the campsite. The road to it peeled off from the main road and wound down to the riverside. There wasn’t a soul in sight. Furthermore, I had no water. None even for drinking, let alone cooking. I had drank it all working my way up the narrow yet scenic mountain road. There were outdoor taps here, but no way to know where they draw from. I checked my map again. Another few kilometers to Mihara, and then another handful more after that to the dam. It was only 15:00…I got to the dam just past 18:00. I was active for a full 12 hours today. And you know what? I was in pretty good shape. Nowhere near as beaten up as I thought I’d be. I had pasta for dinner, alone(?) in the mountains.Animals: 3 cats, 2 snakes, 4 “badgers”Osettai: Citrus, nigiri, candiesPost-trip Addendum:This was the furthest I ever walked in one day. I thought to myself at the time “I could have gone 50”, which means if I really needed to push it or someone’s life was on the line, who knows how far I could go?As I was setting up my tent, a gray van rolled slowly by. I couldn’t see in the windows; the van was filled with trash and belongings. The nearby dam had a control building where employees must be during the day, and I had noticed a number of cars in its parking lot, and yet the building itself seemed dark. My guess was that the cars actually belonged to nomads, just one step away from homelessness. Original Japanese:頑張った日。今、山中のダムの所に居る。三原キャンプ場はなぜか気に入らなくて（誰も居ない、水飲めるか怪しい）先へ進む事にした。ただしこの時点で水がない。三原まで辿るしかない。そしてそこからダムまでは後一時間だけなのでやり抜く事した。丸十二時間の活動。でも出来た。そしてそんなにボロボロではない。剣道２１号の参道は結構好きだった。まるでまたBCに居る。三原村自体も割と活き活きしている。良い町だ。後述：出発五時半頃、安宿に到着十時半頃、分岐に近い十二時頃、camp場を去る三時頃、ダムに到着六時過ぎ。動物：猫３・蛇２・Badger４お接待：小夏・握り・飴#henro #japan #buddhism

records.text: After an epic battle, got SSSD's smartcard support talking to tpm2_pkcs11 (the following assumes you already have smartcard auth working in general):1. Patch tpm2_pkcs11's src/lib/slot.c:slot_get_info to add the CKF_REMOVABLE_DEVICE flag to the slot (sssd ignores non-removable devices). Install the patched version in the usual location, often /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/pkcs11. You can check that it worked with "pkcs11-tool -v -L --module /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/pkcs11/libtpm2_pkcs11.so" which should now include "removable device" in the slot flags.2. Set up a token in /etc/tpm2_pkcs11 with tpm2_ptool or whatever (this can and probably should be owned by root with mode 0600). Provision a suitable certificate, usually the same as on your trad-smartcard.3. Make /dev/tpmrm0 accessible for root: setfacl -m u:root:rw /dev/tpmrm0 (a udev rule can be set up to make this permanent). sssd's default CapabilityBoundingSet prevents p11_child (forked by sssd_pam) from overriding the owner/group for write access even as root.(4. Check SELinux/Apparmor restrictions if you're enforcing that stuff on sssd.)"pamtester lightdm your_username authenticate" should now prompt for the virtual smartcard PIN.If you haven't done it yet, use tpm2_dictionarylockout to set up the DA lockout and then use tpm2_changeauth to set a password on the lockout control object (using a random string and throwing it out is what Windows does and is probably a good idea). Setting up p11-kit-remote to talk to localhost might make it possible to skip some of the permission fuckery.Virtual smartcards may not be a good idea on a portable device (especially since tpm2_pkcs11 doesn't support PCR binding) but probably no worse than password auth on a desktop :shrug:

records.text: Henro Pilgrimage - Day 23 - May 8 (47km)Today I got a glimpse of my limits. At the moment I’m set up for the evening at a large dam in the mountains. I left the cape at 5:30 this morning and headed back up the eastern cost. The weather was perfect. Back near the long beach a local told me not to treck down the rockier path, since the rain had washed out the usual sand bridge. I went anyway and jumped the tiny river that had formed. No issue.By 10:30 I was back at the inn from the previous day and grabbed a quick lunch. That’s already a good 20km walk. There, I talked with the owner about my options for the evening. I was thinking about heading for a campsite a few hours up the road. He suggested I instead go another 10+ km further than that to a dam, saying there’s a park there where I could sleep wherever I want.I’ll get to the campsite first and then weigh my options.By 15:00 I was at the campsite. The road to it peeled off from the main road and wound down to the riverside. There wasn’t a soul in sight. Furthermore, I had no water. None even for drinking, let alone cooking. I had drank it all working my way up the narrow yet scenic mountain road. There were outdoor taps here, but no way to know where they draw from. I checked my map again. Another few kilometers to Mihara, and then another handful more after that to the dam. It was only 15:00…I got to the dam just past 18:00. I was active for a full 12 hours today. And you know what? I was in pretty good shape. Nowhere near as beaten up as I thought I’d be. I had pasta for dinner, alone(?) in the mountains.Animals: 3 cats, 2 snakes, 4 “badgers”Osettai: Citrus, nigiri, candiesPost-trip Addendum:This was the furthest I ever walked in one day. I thought to myself at the time “I could have gone 50”, which means if I really needed to push it or someone’s life was on the line, who knows how far I could go?As I was setting up my tent, a gray van rolled slowly by. I couldn’t see in the windows; the van was filled with trash and belongings. The nearby dam had a control building where employees must be during the day, and I had noticed a number of cars in its parking lot, and yet the building itself seemed dark. My guess was that the cars actually belonged to nomads, just one step away from homelessness. Original Japanese:頑張った日。今、山中のダムの所に居る。三原キャンプ場はなぜか気に入らなくて（誰も居ない、水飲めるか怪しい）先へ進む事にした。ただしこの時点で水がない。三原まで辿るしかない。そしてそこからダムまでは後一時間だけなのでやり抜く事した。丸十二時間の活動。でも出来た。そしてそんなにボロボロではない。剣道２１号の参道は結構好きだった。まるでまたBCに居る。三原村自体も割と活き活きしている。良い町だ。後述：出発五時半頃、安宿に到着十時半頃、分岐に近い十二時頃、camp場を去る三時頃、ダムに到着六時過ぎ。動物：猫３・蛇２・Badger４お接待：小夏・握り・飴#henro #japan #buddhism

records.text: Henro Pilgrimage - Day 23 - May 8 (47km)Today I got a glimpse of my limits. At the moment I’m set up for the evening at a large dam in the mountains. I left the cape at 5:30 this morning and headed back up the eastern cost. The weather was perfect. Back near the long beach a local told me not to treck down the rockier path, since the rain had washed out the usual sand bridge. I went anyway and jumped the tiny river that had formed. No issue.By 10:30 I was back at the inn from the previous day and grabbed a quick lunch. That’s already a good 20km walk. There, I talked with the owner about my options for the evening. I was thinking about heading for a campsite a few hours up the road. He suggested I instead go another 10+ km further than that to a dam, saying there’s a park there where I could sleep wherever I want.I’ll get to the campsite first and then weigh my options.By 15:00 I was at the campsite. The road to it peeled off from the main road and wound down to the riverside. There wasn’t a soul in sight. Furthermore, I had no water. None even for drinking, let alone cooking. I had drank it all working my way up the narrow yet scenic mountain road. There were outdoor taps here, but no way to know where they draw from. I checked my map again. Another few kilometers to Mihara, and then another handful more after that to the dam. It was only 15:00…I got to the dam just past 18:00. I was active for a full 12 hours today. And you know what? I was in pretty good shape. Nowhere near as beaten up as I thought I’d be. I had pasta for dinner, alone(?) in the mountains.Animals: 3 cats, 2 snakes, 4 “badgers”Osettai: Citrus, nigiri, candiesPost-trip Addendum:This was the furthest I ever walked in one day. I thought to myself at the time “I could have gone 50”, which means if I really needed to push it or someone’s life was on the line, who knows how far I could go?As I was setting up my tent, a gray van rolled slowly by. I couldn’t see in the windows; the van was filled with trash and belongings. The nearby dam had a control building where employees must be during the day, and I had noticed a number of cars in its parking lot, and yet the building itself seemed dark. My guess was that the cars actually belonged to nomads, just one step away from homelessness. Original Japanese:頑張った日。今、山中のダムの所に居る。三原キャンプ場はなぜか気に入らなくて（誰も居ない、水飲めるか怪しい）先へ進む事にした。ただしこの時点で水がない。三原まで辿るしかない。そしてそこからダムまでは後一時間だけなのでやり抜く事した。丸十二時間の活動。でも出来た。そしてそんなにボロボロではない。剣道２１号の参道は結構好きだった。まるでまたBCに居る。三原村自体も割と活き活きしている。良い町だ。後述：出発五時半頃、安宿に到着十時半頃、分岐に近い十二時頃、camp場を去る三時頃、ダムに到着六時過ぎ。動物：猫３・蛇２・Badger４お接待：小夏・握り・飴#henro #japan #buddhism

records.text: After an epic battle, got SSSD's smartcard support talking to tpm2_pkcs11 (the following assumes you already have smartcard auth working in general):1. Patch tpm2_pkcs11's src/lib/slot.c:slot_get_info to add the CKF_REMOVABLE_DEVICE flag to the slot (sssd ignores non-removable devices). Install the patched version in the usual location, often /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/pkcs11. You can check that it worked with "pkcs11-tool -v -L --module /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/pkcs11/libtpm2_pkcs11.so" which should now include "removable device" in the slot flags.2. Set up a token in /etc/tpm2_pkcs11 with tpm2_ptool or whatever (this can and probably should be owned by root with mode 0600). Provision a suitable certificate, usually the same as on your trad-smartcard.3. Make /dev/tpmrm0 accessible for root: setfacl -m u:root:rw /dev/tpmrm0 (a udev rule can be set up to make this permanent). sssd's default CapabilityBoundingSet prevents p11_child (forked by sssd_pam) from overriding the owner/group for write access even as root.(4. Check SELinux/Apparmor restrictions if you're enforcing that stuff on sssd.)"pamtester lightdm your_username authenticate" should now prompt for the virtual smartcard PIN.If you haven't done it yet, use tpm2_dictionarylockout to set up the DA lockout and then use tpm2_changeauth to set a password on the lockout control object (using a random string and throwing it out is what Windows does and is probably a good idea). Setting up p11-kit-remote to talk to localhost might make it possible to skip some of the permission fuckery.Virtual smartcards may not be a good idea on a portable device (especially since tpm2_pkcs11 doesn't support PCR binding) but probably no worse than password auth on a desktop :shrug:

records.text: Henro Pilgrimage - Day 23 - May 8 (47km)Today I got a glimpse of my limits. At the moment I’m set up for the evening at a large dam in the mountains. I left the cape at 5:30 this morning and headed back up the eastern cost. The weather was perfect. Back near the long beach a local told me not to treck down the rockier path, since the rain had washed out the usual sand bridge. I went anyway and jumped the tiny river that had formed. No issue.By 10:30 I was back at the inn from the previous day and grabbed a quick lunch. That’s already a good 20km walk. There, I talked with the owner about my options for the evening. I was thinking about heading for a campsite a few hours up the road. He suggested I instead go another 10+ km further than that to a dam, saying there’s a park there where I could sleep wherever I want.I’ll get to the campsite first and then weigh my options.By 15:00 I was at the campsite. The road to it peeled off from the main road and wound down to the riverside. There wasn’t a soul in sight. Furthermore, I had no water. None even for drinking, let alone cooking. I had drank it all working my way up the narrow yet scenic mountain road. There were outdoor taps here, but no way to know where they draw from. I checked my map again. Another few kilometers to Mihara, and then another handful more after that to the dam. It was only 15:00…I got to the dam just past 18:00. I was active for a full 12 hours today. And you know what? I was in pretty good shape. Nowhere near as beaten up as I thought I’d be. I had pasta for dinner, alone(?) in the mountains.Animals: 3 cats, 2 snakes, 4 “badgers”Osettai: Citrus, nigiri, candiesPost-trip Addendum:This was the furthest I ever walked in one day. I thought to myself at the time “I could have gone 50”, which means if I really needed to push it or someone’s life was on the line, who knows how far I could go?As I was setting up my tent, a gray van rolled slowly by. I couldn’t see in the windows; the van was filled with trash and belongings. The nearby dam had a control building where employees must be during the day, and I had noticed a number of cars in its parking lot, and yet the building itself seemed dark. My guess was that the cars actually belonged to nomads, just one step away from homelessness. Original Japanese:頑張った日。今、山中のダムの所に居る。三原キャンプ場はなぜか気に入らなくて（誰も居ない、水飲めるか怪しい）先へ進む事にした。ただしこの時点で水がない。三原まで辿るしかない。そしてそこからダムまでは後一時間だけなのでやり抜く事した。丸十二時間の活動。でも出来た。そしてそんなにボロボロではない。剣道２１号の参道は結構好きだった。まるでまたBCに居る。三原村自体も割と活き活きしている。良い町だ。後述：出発五時半頃、安宿に到着十時半頃、分岐に近い十二時頃、camp場を去る三時頃、ダムに到着六時過ぎ。動物：猫３・蛇２・Badger４お接待：小夏・握り・飴#henro #japan #buddhism
